perturbation.original_text: To maintain all financial records of the Company and provide quarterly and annual reporting to all Company stakeholders. All records are kept under US GAAP compliance standards.
perturbation.changed_text: To maintain financial records of the Company and provide reporting to Company stakeholders when deemed necessary. Records may be kept in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
perturbation.explanation: By changing "all financial records" to just "financial records" and making the reporting schedule discretionary ('when deemed necessary') and the accounting standards vague ('generally accepted accounting principles'), the obligation becomes ambiguous and unenforceable. Removing 'quarterly' and 'annual' removes mandatory timeline that is required, replacing US GAAP with 'generally accepted accounting principles' also allows for manipulation of reporting.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX) and Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (for publicly traded companies)

perturbation.original_text: The Company will ensure timely remittance of all tax liabilities and ensure specific adherence to any specific tax considerations. HGF will ensure maximum tax reduction and where possible elimination of any tax consideration.
perturbation.changed_text: The Company will attempt to remit tax liabilities in a reasonable timeframe and consider tax implications. HGF will explore potential tax reductions and consider possibilities of tax elimination.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "ensure timely remittance" to "attempt to remit…in a reasonable timeframe" and "ensure specific adherence" to "consider tax implications" introduces significant ambiguity. "Reasonable timeframe" is not defined, and merely 'considering' tax implications doesn't guarantee compliance. Similarly, changing "ensure maximum tax reduction…elimination" to "explore potential tax reductions…possibilities of tax elimination" weakens the obligation. Tax laws require strict and timely remittance, and this change makes compliance discretionary and unclear.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) Income Tax Act (since the company is incorporated in Canada)

perturbation.original_text: NVOS and HGF covenant and agree to make their best efforts to fully develop the Primary Projects as well as all projects associated to this agreement as per this agreement at all times faithfully, honestly and diligently perform or cause to be performed their obligations hereunder and to continuously exert best efforts to promote and enhance the business and in that regards they hereby covenant and agree, so long as this Agreement shall remain in effect, to operate the business, as to preserve, maintain and enhance the reputation of NVOS and HGF through the Company.
perturbation.changed_text: NVOS and HGF will endeavor to develop the Primary Projects and associated projects to a reasonable extent. They will aim to perform their obligations in a generally acceptable manner and strive to promote the business when feasible. They will operate the business to avoid significantly damaging the reputation of NVOS and HGF through the Company.
perturbation.explanation: Weakening the "best efforts" standard to a "reasonable extent," replacing "faithfully, honestly, and diligently perform" with "in a generally acceptable manner," and replacing "continuously exert best efforts to promote and enhance" with "strive to promote the business when feasible" all introduce ambiguity and make the obligations far less stringent. Changing "preserve, maintain and enhance the reputation" to "avoid significantly damaging the reputation" lowers the bar significantly. These changes make enforcement difficult and contradict the initial intent of a strong collaborative effort. 'Reasonable extent', 'Generally acceptable manner', and 'when feasible' are also highly subjective.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common Law Contract Principles (Duty of Good Faith and Fair Dealing)
